question_details.query: What are the overall effects of allowing areas of natural or unmanaged vegetation to persist within perennial crops or pastures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Allowing natural or unmanaged vegetation to persist within perennial crops and pastures has multiple documented effects across different biological and agricultural systems. For natural enemies and pest control, studies show mixed results - three studies found varying effects between different groups of natural enemies when comparing natural versus bare ground covers, while two found no difference in enemy numbers in crop canopies (Action 720). In pastures and crops that were left partially uncut, three studies found increased abundance of predatory insects or spiders in the crop field or pasture area, and four studies found more predators in the unharvested or unmown areas themselves (Action 725). Soil health benefits are consistently documented, with four studies showing increased microbial biomass in soils with ground cover compared to bare or tilled soils (Action 2304). For perennial crop systems specifically, twelve studies found more organic matter in soils with ground cover compared to soils without ground cover, and multiple studies documented increased nitrogen levels in covered soils (Action 1367). Ground cover also provided erosion control benefits, with six studies finding less soil erosion in covered areas compared to bare or tilled soils, and four studies showing improved soil aggregate water-stability (Action 1367). Additionally, one study found that olive groves with natural ground cover had higher reptile species richness and diversity than those with bare ground, and more reptiles overall compared to groves with bare ground (Action 3526).
summary_statements: Allowing natural or unmanaged vegetation to persist within perennial crops and pastures has multiple documented effects across different biological and agricultural systems.
Studies have found varying effects between different groups of natural enemies when comparing natural versus bare ground covers.
Some studies found no difference in the numbers of natural enemies in crop canopies when comparing areas with ground cover to areas with bare ground.
In pastures and crops that were left partially uncut, there was an increased abundance of predatory insects or spiders in the crop field or pasture area.
More predators were found in the unharvested or unmown areas of fields and pastures.
Allowing natural or unmanaged vegetation to persist provides consistently documented soil health benefits.
Soils with ground cover have increased microbial biomass compared to bare or tilled soils.
In perennial crop systems, soils with ground cover have more organic matter compared to soils without ground cover.
Multiple studies have documented increased nitrogen levels in soils with ground cover.
Ground cover provides erosion control benefits.
There is less soil erosion in areas with ground cover compared to bare or tilled soils.
Ground cover improves the water-stability of soil aggregates.
Olive groves with natural ground cover had higher reptile species richness and diversity than olive groves with bare ground.
Olive groves with natural ground cover had more reptiles overall compared to olive groves with bare ground.

question_details.query: What are some of the most beneficial interventions for reducing pest populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, beneficial interventions for reducing pest populations include several integrated pest management approaches. Isolating colonies of beneficial ants increases predatory ant occupation in trees, resulting in lower pest damage and higher yields (action 773). Planting flower strips shows greater pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields (action 1400). Using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels provides satisfactory pest control while requiring fewer pesticide applications and lower production costs (action 750). Push-pull cropping systems that combine trap and repellent crops increase parasitism of pest larvae, reduce pest numbers, and provide higher yields and economic benefits (action 753). Excluding ants that protect pests increases parasitism by natural enemies and reduces pest numbers in some studies (action 886). Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use results in acceptable levels of crop damage (action 726). Adding compost to soil reduces some crop diseases (action 1392). Planting hedgerows increases parasitism of pest eggs and reduces pest numbers while increasing natural enemy populations (action 1401). Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increases parasitism and reduces pest numbers in some studies (action 754). Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies increases natural enemy numbers and decreases pest populations and damage while increasing crop yields (action 724). Using mass-emergence devices can increase parasitism rates at some sites (action 775). Leaving part of crops unharvested increases predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs while providing mixed effects on pest numbers (action 725). Mixed pasture systems reduce some pest groups compared to monocultures (action 721). Altering timing of insecticide use can reduce pests and disease damage when applied early rather than late in the growing season (action 723).
summary_statements: Beneficial interventions for reducing pest populations include several integrated pest management approaches.
Isolating colonies of beneficial ants increases predatory ant occupation in trees.
Increased predatory ant occupation in trees results in lower pest damage and higher yields.
Planting flower strips shows greater pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields.
Using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels provides satisfactory pest control.
Using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels requires fewer pesticide applications and lower production costs.
Push-pull cropping systems that combine trap and repellent crops increase parasitism of pest larvae.
Push-pull cropping systems reduce pest numbers and provide higher yields and economic benefits.
Excluding ants that protect pests increases parasitism by natural enemies and reduces pest numbers in some studies.
Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use results in acceptable levels of crop damage.
Adding compost to soil reduces some crop diseases.
Planting hedgerows increases parasitism of pest eggs and reduces pest numbers.
Planting hedgerows increases natural enemy populations.
Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increases parasitism and reduces pest numbers in some studies.
Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies increases natural enemy numbers.
Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies decreases pest populations and damage while increasing crop yields.
Using mass-emergence devices can increase parasitism rates at some sites.
Leaving part of crops unharvested increases predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs.
Leaving part of crops unharvested provides mixed effects on pest numbers.
Mixed pasture systems reduce some pest groups compared to monocultures.
Altering the timing of insecticide use can reduce pests and disease damage when applied early rather than late in the growing season.

question_details.query: What are the potential negative economic impacts on yield and profit from implementing natural pest control strategies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several potential negative economic impacts on yield and profit from implementing natural pest control strategies have been identified. Action 750 found that threshold-based pesticide spraying had inadequate pest control in one study, and one study found that crop damage increased compared to conventional preventative spraying regimes. Action 753 indicated higher production costs in the first year when implementing push-pull cropping systems, though costs became equal or lower in following years. Action 1400 reported inconsistent effects on crop damage by pests when using planted flower strips, with one study finding more damage by caterpillars in tomatoes next to planted flower strips compared to bare ground, and another study finding more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips compared to unplanted field margins. Action 139 showed that reducing pesticides had inconsistent or no effects on some invertebrates or birds in eight studies, and reducing herbicide use had no or mixed effects on birds, invertebrates and plants in five studies. Some studies in Action 750 found mixed effects on yield depending on site, year, pest stage/type, and one study found effects on profits varied between sites and years when using threshold-based spraying compared to conventional regimes.
summary_statements: Several potential negative economic impacts on yield and profit from implementing natural pest control strategies have been identified.
Threshold-based pesticide spraying had inadequate pest control in one study.
One study found that crop damage increased with threshold-based pesticide spraying compared to conventional preventative spraying regimes.
Implementing push-pull cropping systems resulted in higher production costs in the first year.
The costs of push-pull cropping systems became equal or lower in years following the first year of implementation.
Using planted flower strips had inconsistent effects on crop damage by pests.
One study found more damage by caterpillars in tomatoes next to planted flower strips compared to bare ground.
Another study found more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips compared to unplanted field margins.
Reducing pesticides had inconsistent or no effects on some invertebrates or birds in eight studies.
Reducing herbicide use had no or mixed effects on birds, invertebrates and plants in five studies.
Some studies found mixed effects on yield depending on site, year, and pest stage or type.
One study found that effects on profits varied between sites and years when using threshold-based spraying compared to conventional regimes.

question_details.query: As an alternative to creating specific habitats like beetle banks, what other actions can provide refuge for natural enemies from farming operations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several alternatives to beetle banks can provide refuge for natural enemies from farming operations. Plant nectar flower mixture/wildflower strips (Action 442) have been shown to have positive effects on invertebrates, with fifty out of sixty-five studies reporting benefits including increased abundance, species richness/diversity, and evidence that flower strips supported ground beetle species that were rarely found in crops. Plant grass buffer strips/margins around arable or pasture fields (Action 246) increased arthropod abundance, species richness and diversity according to nineteen studies from multiple European countries. Plant nettle strips (Action 118) resulted in a higher number of aphid predator species in field margins, with three insect families including green lacewings only found on nettles. Provide or retain set-aside areas in farmland (Action 156) showed benefits to wildlife groups in twenty studies, providing habitat for overwintering and refuge. Leave overwinter stubbles (Action 695) provides benefits to plants, insects, spiders, mammals and farmland birds, with thirteen studies finding evidence of benefits including higher densities of farmland birds in winter. Leave field margins unsprayed within the crop as conservation headlands (Action 29) creates refuge areas within fields. Plant new hedges (Action 752) can provide habitat for natural enemies, with studies from France and China finding more natural enemies in hedges than in adjacent crops, though effects varied between crop types, hedge species and years. Reduce tillage (Action 126) had positive effects on earthworms and some invertebrates according to thirty-four studies, with increased biomass, species richness or abundance of earthworms and greater abundance of some invertebrates. Take field corners out of management (Action 128) and create uncultivated margins around arable or pasture fields (Action 3518) also provide undisturbed refuge areas for natural enemies.
summary_statements: Several alternatives to beetle banks can provide refuge for natural enemies from farming operations.
Planting nectar flower mixtures or wildflower strips has been shown to have positive effects on invertebrates.
Studies reported that planting wildflower strips resulted in increased abundance and species richness or diversity of invertebrates.
Flower strips have been shown to support ground beetle species that were rarely found in crops.
Planting grass buffer strips or margins around arable or pasture fields increases arthropod abundance, species richness, and diversity.
Planting nettle strips resulted in a higher number of aphid predator species in field margins.
Three insect families, including green lacewings, were only found on nettles in certain studies.
Providing or retaining set-aside areas in farmland showed benefits to wildlife groups.
Set-aside areas in farmland provide habitat for overwintering and refuge for wildlife.
Leaving overwinter stubbles provides benefits to plants, insects, spiders, mammals, and farmland birds.
Studies found that leaving overwinter stubbles resulted in higher densities of farmland birds in winter.
Leaving field margins unsprayed within the crop as conservation headlands creates refuge areas within fields.
Planting new hedges can provide habitat for natural enemies.
Studies from France and China found more natural enemies in hedges than in adjacent crops.
The effects of planting new hedges varied between crop types, hedge species, and years.
Reducing tillage had positive effects on earthworms and some invertebrates.
Reducing tillage led to increased biomass, species richness, or abundance of earthworms.
Reducing tillage resulted in a greater abundance of some invertebrates.
Taking field corners out of management provides undisturbed refuge areas for natural enemies.
Creating uncultivated margins around arable or pasture fields provides undisturbed refuge areas for natural enemies.

question_details.query: In perennial crop systems such as orchards, which interventions are most effective for reducing pest populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents examined, several interventions show effectiveness for reducing pest populations in perennial crop systems such as orchards:

Beneficial ant management is effective, with isolating colonies of beneficial ants leading to higher predatory ant occupation of cashew trees, lower pest damage, and higher yields (Action 773). Conversely, excluding ants that protect pests showed mixed results across different crops, with three of seven studies finding fewer pests, and effects varying between natural enemy species, sampling dates, sites, and crop varieties (Action 886).

Ground cover management through allowing natural regeneration beneath perennial crops shows promise, with four studies measuring pests and crop damage finding that two studies had fewer pests in regenerated versus bare ground covers, though effects varied for different pest or disease groups (Action 720).

Threshold-based pesticide application is an important intervention, with studies showing that using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels can satisfactorily control pests in two of four studies, though one study reported inadequate pest control. This approach typically requires fewer pesticide applications and results in lower production costs (Action 750).

Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests in tomato crops, though this was based on a single study (Action 726).

The evidence comes from various perennial crops including cashew, apple, grape, lemon, olive, pear, cherry, grapefruit, orange, pecan, and satsuma mandarin, though study results often showed mixed effects depending on specific conditions and pest types.
summary_statements: Several interventions show effectiveness for reducing pest populations in perennial crop systems such as orchards.
Beneficial ant management is an effective intervention for reducing pest populations.
Isolating colonies of beneficial ants leads to higher predatory ant occupation of cashew trees.
Isolating colonies of beneficial ants leads to lower pest damage.
Isolating colonies of beneficial ants leads to higher yields.
Excluding ants that protect pests showed mixed results across different crops.
The effects of excluding ants that protect pests varied between natural enemy species, sampling dates, sites, and crop varieties.
Ground cover management through allowing natural regeneration beneath perennial crops shows promise.
Some studies found fewer pests in regenerated ground covers compared to bare ground covers.
The effects of ground cover management varied for different pest or disease groups.
Threshold-based pesticide application is an important intervention.
Using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels can satisfactorily control pests in some cases, though some studies reported inadequate pest control.
Applying pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels typically requires fewer pesticide applications.
Applying pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels results in lower production costs.
Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests in tomato crops.
The finding regarding the incorporation of parasitism rates when setting insecticide thresholds was based on a single study.
The evidence for pest reduction interventions comes from various perennial crops including cashew, apple, grape, lemon, olive, pear, cherry, grapefruit, orange, pecan, and satsuma mandarin.
Study results for pest reduction interventions often showed mixed effects depending on specific conditions and pest types.

question_details.query: What actions involving structural changes within or around fields, like planting trees or grass strips, can be used to enhance natural pest control?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Several structural modifications within or around agricultural fields can enhance natural pest control. Planting grass buffer strips/margins around arable or pasture fields increases arthropod abundance, species richness and diversity, though some studies found no clear effect on invertebrate pest populations (Action 246). Creating beetle banks provides habitat for predatory invertebrates and can result in pest reduction, with the largest pest reductions found in areas closest to beetle banks, though effects on predator movement to adjacent crops can be variable (Action 729). 

Planting flower strips in fields demonstrates mixed results for pest control - some studies found greater pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests, while others found increased pest numbers on crops adjacent to flower strips (Action 1400). Planting nettle strips in field margins resulted in higher numbers of aphid predator species, with certain insect families like green lacewings found only on nettles (Action 118).

Hedgerow establishment and management provides natural pest control benefits. Planting new hedges supports higher abundance of beetles and spiders than crop fields, with literature reviews finding lower pest outbreaks in areas with new hedges (Action 538). Planting hedgerows resulted in higher proportions of parasitized pest eggs in tomato fields compared to fields with weedy edges, though only up to 100 m into the crop, and provided more natural enemies in fields with hedgerows (Action 1401). 

Alley cropping, which involves intercropping with trees, increases diversity of beneficial soil organisms like arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (Action 903). Creating uncultivated margins around fields and taking field corners out of management provide additional structural habitat modifications that support beneficial wildlife, though their direct pest control effects require further study (Actions 190, 3518, 128).
summary_statements: Several structural modifications within or around agricultural fields can enhance natural pest control.
Planting grass buffer strips or margins around arable or pasture fields increases arthropod abundance, species richness, and diversity.
Some studies found that planting grass buffer strips or margins had no clear effect on invertebrate pest populations.
Creating beetle banks provides habitat for predatory invertebrates.
Creating beetle banks can result in pest reduction, with the largest pest reductions found in areas closest to the beetle banks.
The effects of beetle banks on predator movement to adjacent crops can be variable.
Planting flower strips in fields demonstrates mixed results for pest control.
Some studies found that planting flower strips resulted in greater pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests.
Some studies found increased pest numbers on crops adjacent to flower strips.
Planting nettle strips in field margins resulted in higher numbers of aphid predator species.
Certain insect families like green lacewings were found only on nettles when nettle strips were planted.
Hedgerow establishment and management provides natural pest control benefits.
Planting new hedges supports a higher abundance of beetles and spiders than crop fields.
Literature reviews have found lower pest outbreaks in areas with new hedges.
Planting hedgerows resulted in higher proportions of parasitized pest eggs in tomato fields compared to fields with weedy edges.
The effect of higher proportions of parasitized pest eggs from hedgerows was observed up to 100 meters into the crop.
Fields with hedgerows provided more natural enemies of pests.
Alley cropping, which involves intercropping with trees, increases the diversity of beneficial soil organisms like arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi.
Creating uncultivated margins around fields provides additional structural habitat modifications that support beneficial wildlife.
Taking field corners out of management provides additional structural habitat modifications that support beneficial wildlife.
The direct pest control effects of creating uncultivated margins and taking field corners out of management require further study.

question_details.query: What are the alternative strategies to routine, preventative pesticide spraying for managing pests in agricultural production?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several alternative strategies to routine, preventative pesticide spraying exist for managing pests in agricultural production. Threshold-based pesticide application involves using pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach specific threshold levels, which has been shown to require fewer pesticide applications and lower production costs while maintaining similar crop damage and yields compared to conventional spraying regimes (Action 750). 

Crop rotation systems can reduce pest populations and crop diseases, with studies finding fewer insecticide treatments were needed on rotated plots and increased crop yield in some years (Actions 1396, 719). Push-pull cropping systems, which combine trap and repellent crops, have been found to increase parasitism of stem borer larvae, result in more natural predators, fewer pests, less pest damage, and higher yields (Action 753).

Habitat management approaches include planting flower strips, which can provide greater pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms, along with increased numbers of natural enemies (Action 1400). Creating beetle banks has been shown to increase invertebrate predators and can make economic savings if they prevent pests from reaching spray thresholds (Action 729). Alley cropping systems have shown mixed results but can affect natural enemy populations and pest levels (Action 718).

Incorporating biological factors into pest management decisions, such as using parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use, has resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests (Action 726). Organic farming systems have been studied as an alternative approach, showing different effects on various species populations compared to conventional farming (Action 961).
summary_statements: Several alternative strategies to routine, preventative pesticide spraying exist for managing pests in agricultural production.
Threshold-based pesticide application involves using pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach specific threshold levels.

Threshold-based pesticide application has been shown to require fewer pesticide applications and lower production costs while maintaining similar crop damage and yields compared to conventional spraying regimes.
Crop rotation systems can reduce pest populations and crop diseases.
Studies found fewer insecticide treatments were needed on rotated plots in crop rotation systems.
Crop rotation systems have been found to increase crop yield in some years.
Push-pull cropping systems combine trap and repellent crops.
Push-pull cropping systems have been found to increase parasitism of stem borer larvae.
Push-pull cropping systems result in more natural predators and fewer pests.
Push-pull cropping systems result in less pest damage and higher yields.
Habitat management approaches include planting flower strips, which can provide greater pest reduction.
Planting flower strips can lead to higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms.
Planting flower strips can increase the numbers of natural enemies.
Creating beetle banks has been shown to increase invertebrate predators.
Beetle banks can make economic savings if the beetle banks prevent pests from reaching spray thresholds.
Alley cropping systems have shown mixed results but can affect natural enemy populations and pest levels.
Using parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use has resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests.
Organic farming systems have been studied as an alternative approach to conventional farming.
Organic farming systems have shown different effects on various species populations compared to conventional farming.

question_details.query: What are the most effective actions for controlling pests in orchards or other perennial tree crops?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The most effective actions for controlling pests in orchards and perennial tree crops involve multiple integrated approaches based on the evidence from action documents. Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards showed that four replicated controlled studies found more natural enemies in plots with ground cover compared to plots without ground cover, in some or all comparisons (Action 1395). Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops demonstrated that five studies found more natural enemies in natural ground cover, and four studies found fewer pests or lower crop damage, though effects varied for different pest groups (Action 720). Excluding ants that protect pests showed that three of seven studies found fewer pests, and one study found greater tree growth when ants were excluded from trees (Action 886). Isolating colonies of beneficial ants resulted in predatory ants occupying more cashew trees, leading to lower pest damage and higher yields (Action 773). Using chemicals to attract natural enemies showed that five of 13 studies found more natural enemies, three of nine studies found fewer pests, and one study found higher wheat yields (Action 754). Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests in one controlled study (Action 726). Delaying herbicide use increased natural enemies in two randomized, replicated, controlled trials, and one study found fewer pests in one of two experiments (Action 774). Alley cropping showed mixed results, with some studies finding increased natural enemies like wasps and spiders, though effects on pests varied between sites and years (Action 718).
summary_statements: The most effective actions for controlling pests in orchards and perennial tree crops involve multiple integrated approaches.
Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards can result in more natural enemies in plots with ground cover compared to plots without ground cover.
Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops can lead to more natural enemies.
Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops can lead to fewer pests or lower crop damage, though effects can vary for different pest groups.
Excluding ants that protect pests can result in fewer pests.
One study found greater tree growth when ants were excluded from trees.
Isolating colonies of beneficial ants resulted in predatory ants occupying more cashew trees.
The occupation of cashew trees by predatory ants led to lower pest damage and higher yields.
Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can result in more natural enemies.
Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can result in fewer pests.
Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can result in higher wheat yields.
Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests in one controlled study.
Delaying herbicide use increased natural enemies in two randomized, replicated, controlled trials.
Delaying herbicide use was found to result in fewer pests in one of two experiments.
Alley cropping showed mixed results for pest control.
Some studies on alley cropping found increased natural enemies like wasps and spiders.
The effects of alley cropping on pests varied between sites and years.

question_details.query: What are some alternative strategies to routine, preventative insecticide spraying for managing farm pests?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Alternative strategies to routine, preventative insecticide spraying for managing farm pests include several evidence-based approaches. Crop rotation has been shown to reduce pest populations, crop diseases, and the need for insecticide treatments in potato farming systems (719). Push-pull systems that combine trap and repellent crops increase parasitism of stem borer larvae, provide more natural predators, and result in fewer pests with less crop damage and higher yields (753). Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use allows for acceptable levels of crop damage while reducing pesticide applications (726). Planting flower strips increases pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms, while also supporting more natural enemies (1400). Creating beetle banks provides refugia for predatory invertebrates that can reduce pest numbers, particularly in areas closest to the banks (729). Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can increase parasitism and predation rates, though effects vary by chemical type and application conditions (754). Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops can increase natural enemy populations on the ground, with some studies finding fewer pests and reduced crop damage (720). Leaving part of the crop or pasture unharvested provides habitat for predatory insects and spiders, increasing predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs (725). Excluding ants that protect pests can increase parasitism by natural enemies and reduce pest numbers in fruit trees (886), while isolating colonies of beneficial ants can increase predatory ant occupation and reduce pest damage (773). Organic farming systems provide alternatives to synthetic pesticides, though effects on pest management vary by implementation (961).
summary_statements: Alternative strategies to routine, preventative insecticide spraying for managing farm pests include several evidence-based approaches.
Crop rotation has been shown to reduce pest populations and crop diseases in potato farming systems.
Crop rotation can reduce the need for insecticide treatments in potato farming systems.
Push-pull systems that combine trap and repellent crops increase parasitism of stem borer larvae.
Push-pull systems that combine trap and repellent crops provide more natural predators.
Push-pull systems result in fewer pests with less crop damage and higher yields.
Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use allows for acceptable levels of crop damage while reducing pesticide applications.
Planting flower strips increases pest reduction and results in higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms.
Planting flower strips supports more natural enemies.
Creating beetle banks provides refugia for predatory invertebrates.
Predatory invertebrates from beetle banks can reduce pest numbers, particularly in areas closest to the banks.
Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can increase parasitism and predation rates.
The effects of using chemicals to attract natural enemies vary by chemical type and application conditions.
Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops can increase natural enemy populations on the ground.
Natural regeneration of ground cover can lead to fewer pests and reduced crop damage.
Leaving part of the crop or pasture unharvested provides habitat for predatory insects and spiders.
Leaving a portion of a crop or pasture unharvested increases predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs.
Excluding ants that protect pests can increase parasitism by natural enemies in fruit trees.
Excluding ants that protect pests can reduce pest numbers in fruit trees.
Isolating colonies of beneficial ants can increase predatory ant occupation and reduce pest damage.
Organic farming systems provide alternatives to synthetic pesticides.
The effects of organic farming systems on pest management vary by implementation.

question_details.query: What is the evidence that natural pest control interventions can increase the parasitism of pests by natural enemies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from multiple studies demonstrates that various natural pest control interventions can increase parasitism of pests by natural enemies. Excluding ants that protect pests resulted in greater parasitism of pests by natural enemies in one of two replicated, controlled studies from Japan and the USA, with the other study finding greater parasitism at one site but no effect at another (action 886). Push-pull cropping systems increased parasitism of stem borer larvae in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from Kenya, though one study found no effect on egg parasitism (action 753). Planted flower strips led to higher proportions of parasitized pests in three replicated studies from Italy and the USA (action 1400). Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increased parasitism in one review and two of five studies from Asia, Europe and North America, while two studies found greater parasitism for some but not all chemicals, crops, sites or years, and one study found no effect (action 754). Mass-emergence devices resulted in higher parasitism at one site but no effect at another site in one randomised, replicated, controlled study in Switzerland (action 775). Leaving part of the crop unharvested or uncut increased predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in unharvested strips in one replicated, controlled study from Australia (action 725). Alley cropping showed variable effects, with two of four studies from Kenya and the USA finding that effects on parasitism varied between study sites, sampling dates, pest life stages or the width of crop alleys, while two studies found no effect on parasitism (action 718).
summary_statements: Evidence from multiple studies demonstrates that various natural pest control interventions can increase parasitism of pests by natural enemies.
Excluding ants that protect pests resulted in greater parasitism of pests by natural enemies in one of two replicated, controlled studies from Japan and the USA.
One study on excluding ants that protect pests found greater parasitism at one site but no effect at another.
Push-pull cropping systems increased parasitism of stem borer larvae in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from Kenya.
One study on push-pull cropping systems found no effect on egg parasitism.
Planted flower strips led to higher proportions of parasitized pests in three replicated studies from Italy and the USA.
Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increased parasitism in one review and two of five studies from Asia, Europe and North America.
Two studies on using chemicals to attract natural enemies found greater parasitism for some but not all chemicals, crops, sites or years.
One study on using chemicals to attract natural enemies found no effect.
Mass-emergence devices resulted in higher parasitism at one site in one randomised, replicated, controlled study in Switzerland.
The same study in Switzerland on mass-emergence devices found no effect at another site.
Leaving part of the crop unharvested or uncut increased predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in unharvested strips in one replicated, controlled study from Australia.
Two of four studies on alley cropping from Kenya and the USA found that effects on parasitism varied between study sites, sampling dates, pest life stages or the width of crop alleys.
Two studies on alley cropping found no effect on parasitism.
